content: This report highlights the Department of Defense's alternative fuel initiatives, including testing, evaluation, and certification of alternative fuels for service fleets. The Navy is collaborating with other agencies to promote domestic advanced biofuel production. The services have collectively spent around $48 million on these efforts. The Department of Defense aims to boost domestic advanced biofuel production on a commercial scale using the Defense Production Act. The services have invested $48 million in alternative fuels, with the Navy planning a $170 million investment. DOD's purchases of petroleum fuels in FY2011 totaled $17.3 billion. This report provides an overview of DOD's alternative fuels policy, purchases, testing platforms, and certification of alternative fuel blends. The report discusses the current status of the Navy's biofuel production initiative under the Defense Production Act, along with the Department of Energy and Agriculture. It also provides information on legislative actions related to DOD's alternative fuels efforts. The Navy's biofuel production efforts under the Defense Production Act are discussed in CRS Report R42568. The Department of Defense's operational energy efforts, including biofuels, are covered in CRS Report R42558. Section 314 of the FY2012 National Defense Authorization Act assigned oversight of DOD's alternative fuels initiatives to the Assistant Secretary of Defense. Section 314 of the FY2012 National Defense Authorization Act assigned responsibility for DOD's alternative fuels initiatives and policy to the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Operational Energy Plans and Programs, providing oversight and leadership in developing alternative fuels within the military departments and the Office of the Secretary of Defense. The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Operational Energy Plans and Programs is responsible for developing alternative fuels within the military departments and the Office of the Secretary of Defense. Recommendations include issuing guidelines to streamline alternative fuels investments and collaborating with other federal agencies for the benefit of DOD. Sharon Burke's memorandum outlines the goals of DOD alternative fuels policy to ensure operational military readiness and improve battlespace effectiveness. The DOD alternative fuels policy aims to enhance military readiness, battlespace effectiveness, and fuel source diversity. Investments in alternative fuels seek to increase resilience, reduce price volatility effects, provide more fuel options, and enhance expeditionary effectiveness. Alternative fuels for DOD use must be drop-in and cost-competitive with conventional petroleum. DOD officials require alternative fuels for operational use to be "drop-in," cost-competitive, and available in sufficient quantities. Other desired characteristics include production from non-food crop feedstock and lower lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions. DOD investments in alternative fuel activities must be certified as part of the annual operational energy budget process. The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Operational Energy Plans and Programs reviews proposed budgets to ensure adequacy for implementation. The Assistant Secretary of Defense for Operational Energy Plans and Programs reviews proposed budgets to certify adequacy for implementing the operational energy strategy. The annual operational energy report now includes alternative fuels initiatives, with future investments subject to a rigorous evaluation process. DOD alternative fuels development follows three phases, starting with a certification phase involving a cross-services fuels working group. Phase 1: Certification involves a cross-services fuels working group submitting an annual plan for alternative fuels. Phase 2: Field Demonstration may be proposed for a new fuel, reviewed by the Office of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Operational Energy Plans and Programs. Phase 3: Ongoing. Phase 3 involves ongoing purchases of alternative fuels, competing with petroleum products based on best value to the government. Each military service has set goals for alternative fuels, with the Army aiming to increase the use of renewable/alternative energy according to the Army Energy Security Implementation Strategy. The Army aims to increase the use of renewable/alternative energy, with goals set out in the Army Energy Security Implementation Strategy. By 2028, they aim for 25% of energy for tactical power generation to come from renewable sources and 50% of fuel for the training base fleet to be alternative fuel blends. The Air Force aims to competitively acquire 50% of its domestic aviation fuel. The Air Force aims to acquire 50% of its domestic aviation fuel from alternative fuel blends by 2016, derived from greener domestic sources. They also plan to test and certify all aircraft on a 50:50 alternative fuel blend by 2012. The Navy has set ambitious goals for alternative fuels, including deploying a "Great Green Fleet" by 2016 and aiming to meet 50% of energy consumption from alternative sources by 2020. This fleet consists of ships and aircraft running on biofuel blends. The Navy aims to meet 50% of its energy consumption from alternative sources by 2020, with plans to reduce liquid fuel usage afloat. Approximately 8 million barrels of petroleum used afloat would need to be replaced by unblended alternative fuels to achieve this goal. Since 2007, DLA Energy has procured approximately 1.9 million gallons of various types of alternative fuels on behalf of the Army, Navy, and Air Force using funds provided by the services. Section 526 of the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 prohibits federal agencies, including DOD, from entering into contracts for alternative fuels with high greenhouse gas emissions. The Department of Defense (DOD) excludes coal-to-liquid fuels with high greenhouse gas emissions from alternative fuel purchases. DOD's position is that EISA section 526 does not apply to fuel purchases where the source is unspecified in the contract. The Army, Navy, and Air Force are testing alternative fuel blends for potential fleet-wide use. The Army, Navy, and Air Force are testing alternative fuel blends for potential fleet-wide use. The Army is currently testing 50:50 blends of Fischer-Tropsch synthetic paraffinic kerosene and hydrotreated renewable jet with JP-8 for use in all Army ground systems and field generators, with the goal of certifying these fuels by 2014. The Army is also working to obtain Air Force certification for H-60 Black Hawk helicopters to fly on the 50:50 FT-SPK: JP-8 blend. The Army and Air Force are testing alternative fuel blends for their ground equipment and aviation systems. The Army aims to complete testing by the end of FY2014, while the Air Force has certified Fischer-Tropsch fuel blends for its fleets and is testing biofuels for fleet-wide certification. The Air Force has completed testing on biofuels for its manned and unmanned fleets, including alcohol-to-jet fuels. The Navy has also tested biofuel blends for its aircraft and ships. Fischer-Tropsch fuels testing and certification is set to be finished by the end of 2013. Other alternative fuels like alcohol-to-jet and pyrolysis oils will continue to be tested in the future.
